description.narrative: The specific outcome is to strengthen the quality of maternal health services, which is linked to the result framework of Bangladesh´s Health Sector Programme HPNSDP 2011-2016: Increased utilisation of essential HPN services, Maternal neonatal and child health, family planning and reproductive Health. The intervention will make a direct contribution to the achievement of the national development goals in order to reach MDG 5 on maternal health and MDG 4 on child health.

This intervention targets the overarching development problem to reach the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) 5 (maternal health) and child health(MDG4) in Bangladesh. The maternal mortality ratio is still high, Moreover, child marriage and resulting adolescent pregnancy still pose significant problems in the country. The need of educated midwives is high and it is need of health system strengthening and increased quality of care. As a way forward to reach the MDG 5 and MDG 4 the Prime Minister of Bangladesh Sheik Hasina made a commitment year 2010 to educate and deploy 3000 midwives educated according to international standards.current Sweden together with other development partners has been supporting Health Sector Program (HPNSDP) 2011-2016, with MSEK 415.
The Government of Bangladesh, specifically the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, is acutely aware of the gaps in the legal and policy framework to support the new cadre of midwives and has sought assistance to support the weak institutional capacity. There are technical gaps in development inputs on issues pertaining to maternity development in Bangladesh. While some of the technical issues are being addressed on an ongoing basis – such as policy development for human resources management, under the existing HPNSDP – other issues require more immediate and intensive inputs, specifically relating to availability. A set of policies and regulations needs to be urgently developed and put in place, in order to ensure appropriate placement and distribution of individuals, mentoring, supervision and career path planning.
A resource envelope for technical assistance is available through Sida to be utilised to address the issues of policy and legal framework for midwives, strengthening the capacity of the training establishments, strengthening midwife-led care, advocacy to increase utilisation of midwife-led deliveries and improve the provision of emergency obstetric and neonatal care in supported districts. A focused support to technical assistance to strengthen the Quality of Maternal Health Services will benefit the overarching goal to reach MDG 5 and MDG 4.
This project will make a direct contribution to the achievement of the national development goals as stipulated in the current Health Population and Nutrition Sector Development Program (HPNSDP) especially its goal to “Increase utilization of essential HPN services: maternal, neonatal, and child health, family planning and reproductive health, nutrition services, communicable diseases”. The capacity support at national level to a range of Government agencies will ensure that the preparatory work to establish guidelines, regulations, licensing arrangements, scope of work (job descriptions), and relationships vis a vis other health care professionals is in place across the country by the time the newly qualified midwives become available for service in December 2015.
Direct skills training (for supervision, mentoring, professional development planning, curriculum development), training of trainers (for implementation of the skills-based curriculum), policy advice (on regulations, deployment, recruitment and retention policies, licensing and accreditation of training institutions), will all be employed.
The time limited grant from SIDA (August 2015 – 30 June 2016) offers UNFPA the opportunity to kick start a series of inputs and interventions which support the Government’s policy of creating a cadre of professionally qualified midwives who will provide clinically up to date delivery services as well as EmONC services. The Results and Resources Framework clearly links the proposed one year programme to national priorities as articulated in the HPNSDP, in United Nations Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF), and in the UNFPA’s global Strategic Plan and Country Programme.
The recently appointed International Midwifery Technical Specialist and the National Midwifery Programme Officer of UNFPA will provide technical, co-ordination and managerial support to the national and international consultants to ensure the smooth running of the scheduled inputs to support achievement of the outputs within the designated one year time frame.

UNFPA Bangladesh har ansökt om stöd från Sverige för att genomföra projektet ”Technical Assistance to Strengthen the Quality of Maternal Health Services” på 9 500 000 SEK för perioden, 15 november 2015 – 31 december 2016.
Insatsen gäller tekniskt stöd från UNFPA i form av överföring av sakkunskap och rådgivning till hälsoministeriet. De svenska medlen kommer främst att finansiera en internationell och en nationell barnmorskespecialist som under ledning av UNFPA ska ge stöd till hälsoministeriet att bygga upp verksamheten kring barnmorskeyrket i Bangladesh. UNFPA ska bistå hälsoministeriet i utformningen av det legala och institutionella ramverket för yrkesutövningen samt vid utformningen av den nya barnmorskeutbildningen. Sedan 2012 har hälsoministeriet genomfört flera insatser för att introducera barnmorskeyrket i Bangladesh. Under 2015 och 2016 förväntas arbetet med det institutionella ramverket för yrkesutövandet samt tillsynen över yrkesutövningen intensifieras, vilket motiverar det svenska stödet.
Insatsens totala budget är på 15 000 000 SEK för en ett-års period där UNFPAs egen insats uppgår till 5 500 000 SEK.
English Summary Sweden provides 450 000 000 SEK over 4 years to the Government of Bangladesh to implement the national Health, Population and Nutrition Sector Development Programme. Up to 15 000 000 SEK are provided for technical assistance and to cover costs including monitoring and evaluation. It is proposed that 9 500 000 SEK are allocated for technical assistance to UNFPA and the implementation of the programme ”Technical Assistance to Strengthen the Quality of Maternal Health Services” during the period 15th November, 2015 – 31st December, 2016.
The technical assistance from UNFPA will facilitate specific midwifery training and regulatory functions. The support will make a contribution to the training of midwifes and streamlining the recruitment and promotion of midwifes as a new cadre of health professionals. Also, UNFPA will support the MoH to develop policy formulation for midwifery, operating procedures for this new profession, as well as strengthening quality assurance of the profession. During 2015 and 2016 this efforts will be intensified, which motivates the short-term support from Sweden.

description.narrative: Achievements: 1. Master programme in SRHR created. 2. Five Centers of Excellence (CoE) for midwifery education created. 3. The midwifery-led care model introduced in the sub-district hospitals of Chittagong, Dhala, Moulzibazar, Rangpur and Sylhet. 4. 1200 midwifes deployed to Upazila Health complexes. 5. National Emergency Obstetric and Newborn Care Plan developed. 6. The enactment of the National Nursing and Midwifery Act.
